newsitem.title: GREECE: Greek short rates ease, bonds flat, ecu/drs idles.
newsitem.headline: Greek short rates ease, bonds flat, ecu/drs idles.

text.p: Greek short-run interbank depos and forex forwards were driven lower by improved liquidity conditions, long tenors were easier and bonds were little changed with two-year zeros and T-bills hitting the market, dealers said.
Ecu/drachma was locked in familiar ranges, currently trading around 309.40/45.

"There is more liquidity and as a result short-term rates have eased about a fourth of a point," said a senior dealer at a private bank. "Long-term rates are also trading five to 10 basis points lower."
The trader said liquidity could be further boosted if sales of zeros and T-bills did not cover maturities. About 200 billion drachmas of 12-month T-bills expire today.
Greece issues 12-month T-bills and two-year zeros at a gross rate of 9.60 percent and 9.50 percent respectively today.
Bonds were fluctuating in tight ranges with players awaiting to see how the zeros and 12-month T-bill would fare today.

"Trading activity is subdued and bond prices are frozen with the market focusing on T-bills and two-year zeros," a bond dealer said. "Some banks have come up with some financial instruments offering more attractive interest rates that the state's."
The mark was quoted at 157.73/83 from Monday's 157.685 fix, the dollar at 275.32/42 drachmas from 275.220 and the ecu at 310.17/27 from 309.330 drachmas.
"Ecu/drachma opened at 309.46/51 and eased a bit to trade currently around 309.40/45," said a forex trader at a foreign bank.
